oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Tah-Chee
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Portrait of Cherokee leader Tah-Chee shown wearing a lavender tunic with a dagger tucked into a green sash belted around the waist. His headdress is topped with a large red feather.

Tah-Chee (the Cherokee word for "Dutch") was born circa 1790 in present-day Alabama but became one of the earliest Cherokees to remove west of the Mississippi, settling south of the Arkansas River. He led a renegade band of Cherokees intent on resisting Federal authority and warring on neighboring tribes, particularly the Osages. He later became a valuable guide and hunter for the government, attending the 1835 CampHomes Treaty. He later settled in Texas until he was forcibly relocated to Oklahoma, where he died in 1848.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: McKenney, Thomas L. (Thomas Loraine), 1785-1859; Hall, James, 1793-1868
